citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, the following animals were identified in need of veterinary care and the facility did not communicate
the condition to the Attending Veterinarian:
- An adult female goat #1576 was found to be non-weight bearing on the back right leg with the animal’s hoof missing. On
8/1/2025, the facility noted this condition, separated the animal, and gave Zactran. This particular condition is not covered
in the protocols approved by the Attending Veterinarian. The Attending Veterinarian was called and stated that they were
not notified about this animal's condition.
-An adult female pregnant goat #792 was found to be down. On 8/1/2025, the facility noted this condition and separated
the animal. This particular condition is not covered in the protocols approved by the Attending Veterinarian and the facility
did not contact the Attending Veterinarian.
During the inspection, the following animals were observed in need of veterinary care. These animals were not identified
by facility personnel prior to the inspection:
-An adult goat with ear tag # 801 was observed limping on the left front leg while in motion and non-weight bearing when
stationary.
-An adult goat with ear tag # 1968 was observed limping and non-weight bearing while in motion on the right front leg.
-An adult goat with ear tag # 825 was observed limping on the right forelimb while in motion.
-An adult goat with ear tag # 871 was observed limping on the left front leg while in motion.
-An adult sheep with ear tag # 1746 was observed limping while in motion and toe touching when at rest. The animal
occasionally held up the right front leg when stationary.
-An adult sheep with ear tag # OH3321712 was observed limping on the right front leg while in motion.
-An adult sheep with ear tag # 921 was observed limping when in motion and consistently non-weight bearing on the right
rear leg when not in motion.
Failure to conduct adequate daily observations to assess the health and well-being of the animals with direct and frequent
communication to the attending veterinarian can delay treatment leading to the condition getting worse and delays in
healing. Each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily
observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being and that a mechanism of direct and frequent
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. Correct by ensuring that these animals are examined and treated by a licensed
veterinarian. Correct by Close of Business 7-AUGUST-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.33(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care. 
During the inspection, the following animals were identified in need of veterinary care and the facility did not communicate 
the condition to the Attending Veterinarian: 
 
- An adult female goat #1576 was found to be non-weight bearing on the back right leg with the animal’s hoof missing. On 
8/1/2025, the facility noted this condition, separated the animal, and gave Zactran. This particular condition is not covered 
in the protocols approved by the Attending Veterinarian. The Attending Veterinarian was called and stated that they were 
not notified about this animal's condition.  
 
-An adult female pregnant goat #792 was found to be down. On 8/1/2025, the facility noted this condition and separated 
the animal. This particular condition is not covered in the protocols approved by the Attending Veterinarian and the facility 
did not contact the Attending Veterinarian. 
 
During the inspection, the following animals were observed in need of veterinary care. These animals were not identified 
by facility personnel prior to the inspection: 
 
-An adult goat with ear tag # 801 was observed limping on the left front leg while in motion and non-weight bearing when 
stationary.  
-An adult goat with ear tag # 1968 was observed limping and non-weight bearing while in motion on the right front leg.  
-An adult goat with ear tag # 825 was observed limping on the right forelimb while in motion.  
-An adult goat with ear tag # 871 was observed limping on the left front leg while in motion.  
-An adult sheep with ear tag # 1746 was observed limping while in motion and toe touching when at rest. The animal 
occasionally held up the right front leg when stationary. 
-An adult sheep with ear tag # OH3321712 was observed limping on the right front leg while in motion. 
-An adult sheep with ear tag # 921 was observed limping when in motion and consistently non-weight bearing on the right 
rear leg when not in motion.  
 
 
Failure to conduct adequate daily observations to assess the health and well-being of the animals with direct and frequent

communication to the attending veterinarian can delay treatment leading to the condition getting worse and delays in 
healing. Each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily 
observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being and that a mechanism of direct and frequent 
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being 
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. Correct by ensuring that these animals are examined and treated by a licensed 
veterinarian. Correct by Close of Business 7-AUGUST-2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
